top_procedures.description: Established patient office or other outpatient, visit typically 40 minutes

Testing for presence of drug
Established patient office or other outpatient, visit typically 25 minutes
Drug screen, qualitative; multiple drug classes by high complexity test method (e.g., immunoassay, enzyme assay), per patient encounter

Drug tests(s), presumptive, any number of drug classes; any number of devices or procedures by instrumented chemistry analyzers utilizing immunoassay, enzyme assay, TOF, MALDI, LDTD, DESI, DART, GHPC, GC mass spectrometry), includes sample validation when

Drug test(s), definitive, utilizing (1) drug identification methods able to identify individual drugs and distinguish between structural isomers (but not necessarily stereoisomers), including, but not limited to gc/ms (any type, single or tandem) and lc/ms
Injections of anesthetic and/or steroid drug into lower or sacral spine nerve root using imaging guidance
New patient office or other outpatient visit, typically 30 minutes

Drug test(s), definitive, utilizing (1) drug identification methods able to identify individual drugs and distinguish between structural isomers (but not necessarily stereoisomers), including, but not limited to gc/ms (any type, single or tandem) and lc/ms
Injections of lower or sacral spine facet joint using imaging guidance
Injections of anesthetic and/or steroid drug into lower or sacral spine nerve root using imaging guidance

Injections of lower or sacral spine facet joint using imaging guidance
Alcohol (ethanol) level
Alcohol (ethanol); any specimen except breath

Injection of substance into spinal canal of lower back or sacrum using imaging guidance
Prolonged patient service without direct patient contact first hour
